question: how do you expect international business to change in a post covid-19 landscape?

clueweb22-en0006-83-03859.point_content: International business partnerships are likely to grow after COVID-19 ends despite calls for protectionism.
spans: Though it may seem difficult to believe in the current state of quarantine and closure, it is likely that these types of overseas connections will actually grow.

clueweb22-en0006-83-03859.point_content: Businesses will diversify their overseas suppliers and partners to avoid future supply chain disruptions.
spans: the best recovery tactic for businesses may be to diversify their overseas suppliers, vendors and other relationships to ensure they can produce, regardless of any future localized delays or stoppages.

clueweb22-en0006-83-03859.point_content: International partnerships provide cost savings, access to talent, and scaling opportunities that are unlikely to be replaced by localization.
spans: There are numerous reasons to partner with an international vendor, the most obvious of which is a cost-saving benefit.
Additionally, foreign partnerships allow for growth in ways that may not be available locally including sourcing international talent and scaling operations to increase output.

clueweb22-en0006-83-03859.point_content: International sourcing allows businesses to access new customer markets, which is important for growth especially given demographic shifts.
spans: One of the biggest – yet least discussed – benefits of international sourcing is gaining access to a new audience.
Demographic shifts have also long played a part in a business’s need for accessing other markets.

clueweb22-en0006-83-03859.point_content: The US-China trade war caused some businesses to move operations to other countries, increasing diversification rather than reducing international business.
spans: Because of the sheer volume, businesses will likely diversify their overseas relationships, rather than sever them.
Already there is evidence of foreign contracts moving from a single source like China to Vietnam, Mexico, India and many more.

clueweb22-en0006-83-03859.point_content: Past crises show that diversifying international partnerships aids recovery and resilience rather than isolation or protectionism.
spans: The reliance on a single location demonstrated the need for expansion, not isolation.
Global partnerships were a major factor in the eventual market recovery from the 2008 Financial Crisis.

clueweb22-en0006-83-03859.point_content: After COVID-19, businesses can expect to work with more overseas partners, not fewer, as international partnerships are vital for economic recovery and growth.
spans: As such, once the local closures are lifted, businesses can expect to work with more overseas partners – not fewer.

Create a stronger customer and team member experience by investing time and money on the things that matter most.
Start from the top, with a leadership team and ethos culturally committed to increasing our work-from-home footprint and team member flexibility and choice.
Be a leader in workplace flexibility with a goal of 50% (or greater in countries with the right infrastructure) of our team members in flexible work arrangements.

clueweb22-en0044-06-02322.point_content: Return to site strategies must prioritize health and wellbeing, using data and science, local regulations, and phased return to site plans.

Return to site risk assessment – Evaluate the infection rates, active cases, recovery and scaled increase trends of the country/specific location to determine how safe it is for team members to return to site.
Pre-opening readiness – Assess and prepare for team members to return to site while ensuring hygiene, social distancing, and infrastructure all support team member health and productivity.

Phased return to site – Start with those team members who are physically required to be onsite, and gradually move to those functions and people who prefer to come to their place of work; as well as accommodating those who don’t feel comfortable to return.
Communication – Develop transparent and frequent communications, with a feedback loop, to team members and communities.

clueweb22-en0043-19-05906.point_content: Companies must adapt to new customer values post-COVID-19 and develop new use cases and tailored experiences.
spans: Companies need to understand what customers will value, post-COVID-19, and develop new use cases and tailored experiences based on those insights.

clueweb22-en0043-19-05906.point_content: Adaptability and changing ecosystems with nontraditional collaborations will be essential due to crisis-related disruptions in supply chains and channels.
spans: Given crisis-related disruptions in supply chains and channels, adaptability is essential. That will mean changing the ecosystem and considering nontraditional collaborations with partners up and down the supply chain.

clueweb22-en0043-19-05906.point_content: Successful companies will redesign their operations and supply chains to protect against a wider and more acute range of potential shocks, accelerating regionalization of supply chains.
spans: Successful companies will redesign their operations and supply chains to protect against a wider and more acute range of potential shocks. In addition, they will act quickly to rebalance their global asset base and supplier mix. The once-prevalent global-sourcing model in product-driven value chains has steadily declined as new technologies and consumer-demand patterns encourage regionalization of supply chains. We expect this trend to accelerate.

clueweb22-en0043-19-05906.point_content: Leading innovators use Industry 4.0 digital and analytics tools to reduce the cost of flexibility and improve productivity, flexibility, quality, and customer connectivity.
spans: leading innovators have demonstrated how “Industry 4.0” (or the Fourth Industrial Revolution suite of digital and analytics tools and approaches) can significantly reduce the cost of flexibility. In short, low-cost, high-flexibility operations are not only possible—they are happening.

clueweb22-en0043-19-05906.point_content: The future of work will involve more automation and technology, remote work, and a shift towards analytical and technical skills, requiring investment in workforce engagement and training.
spans: The future of work, defined by the use of more automation and technology, was always coming. COVID-19 has hastened the pace. Employees across all functions, for example, have learned how to complete tasks remotely, using digital communication and collaboration tools. In operations, changes will go further, with an accelerated decline in manual and repetitive tasks and a rise in the need for analytical and technical support. This shift will call for substantial investment in workforce engagement and training in new skills, much of it delivered using digital tools.

clueweb22-en0043-19-05906.point_content: Organizations are shifting to flatter structures with faster decision making, more delegation, and a focus on character and results over expertise or experience.
spans: a flatter organization that delegates decision making down to a dynamic network of teams is more effective. They are rewiring their circuits to make decisions faster, and with much less data and certainty than before.
the premium is placed on character and results, rather than on expertise or experience.

clueweb22-en0043-19-05906.point_content: Companies are moving from closed systems to digital platforms and networks of mutually beneficial partnerships, which have proved more resilient during the crisis.
spans: Those organizations that are making the shift from closed systems and one-to-one transactional relationships to digital platforms and networks of mutually beneficial partnerships have proved more resilient during the crisis.

clueweb22-en0043-19-05906.point_content: Digital adoption has accelerated dramatically, and digital will play a defining role in the COVID-19 recovery.
spans: These changes have accelerated the migration to digital technologies at stunning scale and speed, across every sector.
Through the COVID-19 recovery, too, digital will play a defining role.

clueweb22-en0043-19-05906.point_content: Leaders will need to set an ambitious digital agenda and deliver it quickly, focusing on customer expectations, data and AI for operations, tech modernization, and speed of digital solutions.
spans: leaders will need to set an ambitious digital agenda—and deliver it quickly, on the order of two to three months, as opposed to the previous norm of a year or more.

clueweb22-en0043-19-05906.point_content: Companies need to rethink customer journeys and accelerate digital solutions development to adapt to changing customer expectations.
spans: companies need to quickly rethink customer journeys and accelerate the development of digital solutions.

clueweb22-en0043-19-05906.point_content: Companies need to incorporate new data and create new models for real-time decision making, recalibrating data and analytics to the post-COVID-19 reality.
spans: companies need to incorporate new data and create new models to enable real-time decision making.
the use of data and analytics will need to be recalibrated to reflect the post-COVID-19 reality.

clueweb22-en0043-19-05906.point_content: Companies must improve IT productivity, reduce IT costs, adopt cloud and automation technologies, and develop new skills and roles to support digital platforms.
spans: Companies will also need to greatly improve their IT productivity to lower their cost base and fund rapid, flexible digital-solution development.
the adoption of cloud and automation technologies will need to be speeded up, including bringing cloud operations on-premise and decommissioning legacy infrastructure.

clueweb22-en0043-19-05906.point_content: Companies need to integrate business processes, data-driven decision making, and change management to deliver digital solutions at scale.
spans: Solving this “last mile” challenge requires integrating businesses processes, incorporating data-driven decision making, and implementing change management.
